reviewText: A modern classic, Freddi Fish 2: The Case of the Haunted Schoolhouse is a clever (albeit blatant) satire on the McCarthyism era in United States history. Although I found it to be quite monotonous in storytelling, the character development and dialogue was some of the best we've seen this decade. If you're looking for a real work of art, Freddi Fish 2: The Case of the Haunted Schoolhouse is for you.

reviewText: Arguably the definitive game of a generation, it blends post-modern philosophical themes with beautiful storytelling to create a game that will be revered for decades to come. Few games have dared to stray into the territory that Freddi Fish 2: The Case of the Haunted Schoolhouse does. It was revolutionary in its time for its allegory of the Book of Job from the Bible. Along with Put-Put, Freddi Fish will always have a prominent place in the halls of American literature.

reviewText:
To begin the review, I would like to give initial thoughts. Starting the game I could already tell this was a master piece. The stunning visuals and superb sound quality left me absolutely awestruck. The downside to the unbelievable graphics is that I could only run this game at about 98-100fps on mega ultra settings.

The story is quite linear with several sidequests that interweave with the main storyline, similar to The Witcher 3: Wildhunt, but was executed far better in my opinion. The characters, unlike in The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt are not 1 dimensional and have interesting personalities and backstories. For me, the most memorable quest was finding the glasses in the hole, I can vividly remember recieving my first weapon as a reward: A scoped slingshot. It was easily the best weapon in the game, but since I had specced into intelligence it was practically useless. This makes the combat far harder, I remember the final battle against the ghost took me several tries to beat. This is not helped by the unweildy combat system that utilises QTES(Quick Time Events) which seem very out of place, considering this is kids game. In several areas of the huge open world map, there are big scary male fish that try to oppress you with musical instruments. You have the option to initiate combat with them, but it takes a lot of grinding in order to get to their level.

There is a high level of interaction within the environment, my favourite place is the movie theatre, with the right button combination you are able to play reruns of the hit tv show, The Fresh Prince of Belair. Other than the horrible combat system, another gripe i have this game is the economy, it is very clear that the octopus has a monopoly over the entire pulley market, as one pulley will often run you 5 sea urchins, which can be very difficult to come across, while exploring the gigantic open world. My last gripe is this game, is more of a personal one, after playing for a while I literally developed cancer, this game cost me so much money, that i was unabable to pay for my hospital bills. Since this is the only game I own I am just sitting in the hospital playing this game, waiting for the sweet, sweet release of death.

Best game ever 10/10

This game sucks fish sticks

reviewText:
tl;dr: If ya played it as a kid or are getting it for kids, buy it. If you're an adult and have never played this game, it's almost certainly not going to do anything for ya, and ya should probably pass on it.


This game and any other Humongous Entertainment game should only be bought for one of two reasons:

1) You're getting it as a game for your young kids. That's how I was introduced to this game and it's stuck with me ever since. Freddi Fish, Pajama Sam, Spy Fox, Putt-Putt, they're all nostalgia mascots for my childhood and even playing this game now I still love these characters; as cheesy as they all may be now.

2) You're like me and are reliving your childhood games. Trust me, even though this game is easy as hell and you can blast through it in under an hour, it's still fun to relive a game that you enjoyed as a kid.

I spent a ton of the time I was on this game just screwin' around with the environmental stuff, which is half the fun of these old HE games. The story's stupid and would make Scooby Doo hang his head in shame of how laughable this mystery" is
date: but it's still entertaining as hell to play through just so you can swim around the ocean
recommended: meet all of the Freddis' pals
hoursPlayed: and just see what you can do."

reviewText:
Freddi Fish 2 is one of the very first PC games I ever played. I played it off a CD I got in a cereal box on my dad's ancient Windows 95 computer, which I had for about 10 years.

This is a game I have this strange nostalgic fondness for despite fundamentally being a simple kids game. The plot centers on the two characters, Freddi and Luther, who have to discover the identity of a mysterious ghost who steals the toys of all of the other children. And they have to gather various objects inorder to build a trap to capture the ghost. Like I said it is fundamentally a children's game so the humor is a bit predictable, the puzzles are very simple and you're frequently told what to do and what to get. (IE: Freddi says you need scissors to cut some kelp, you need a wrench to remove a wheel, you need to ask a character for a combination to a lock. Etc.)

Something the game does have much like other Humungous games is random elements. When you start the game up, certain elements are removed wheras others appear. For instance, all of the trap items you need to locate are randomized during every playthrough. While this isn't that big of a difference it does make the second or third playthrough feel different. When I was a kid this blew me away at the time but nowadays it just feels like a way to pad out the game time. Since it is a very short game.

Going through it on the first try you can beat the game in maybe 30 minutes. This is a common aspect of Humungous games compared to other SCUMM games like the ones by Lucasarts. So it might not hold your attention as an adult, but it will return you back to a day when you were a kid, and every game was a treasure to behold.

reviewText: During the late 90’s/early 2000’s Humongous Entertainment released an absolutely fantastic stream of “edutainment” point and click adventures for children. These titles focus on a range of light academics including basic geography, basic to upper elementary level mathematics, logical thinking, critical thinking and puzzle solving, topped off with reinforcement of good manners and polite social etiquette. At the lower end of the age spectrum, they may require some adult supervision and supportive guidance, but there is no better series of games for a child’s first venture into PC gaming.\n\nI played the Haunted Schoolhouse right after finishing the Kelp Seed adventure and I remember not being okay with the whole “Haunted” part. Between the already scary sharks, and then some sort of paranormal activity in an elementary school, I remember that this game really frightened me at first. I think it was almost a year before I went back and actually really enjoyed it. It is by no means inappropriate, but I would recommend some supervision at first until you see how your child reacts to some of the opening scenes and concepts.

reviewText: Before I get too in depth in this full on review let me start by saying this. Freddi Fish 2: The Case of the Haunted Schoolhouse is by far one of the best gaming experiences of our generation. The challenging mental puzzles will leave you breathless as you try comprehend their hidden meanings. The answers are always as they seem, though an experienced veteran of the cloak and dagger genre will find a way to prolong to mystery. I cannot state enough how impactful this game is to the gaming communtiy and I feel it is my oblogation to convey this simple message. Freddi Fish 2: The Case of the Haunted Schoolhouse is a refreshing take on the childrens click entertainment platformer series. It's endless innovations are awe inspiring. However, some users may find the graphics somewhat lackluster compaired to franchises such as Far Cry or the Elder Scrolls series. Let me make this abundantly clear... You wasting precious moments of your temporary existence by passing this game off as childs play. Freddi Fish2: The Case of the Haunted Schoolhouse will enchant your senses with its gripping story telling and rich user interaction. I beg you buy this game, not just for me but treat yourself to something miraculous. Games like Freddi Fish2: The Case of the Haunted Schoolhouse come around once, maybe twice in a decade. Don't become one of the mindless drones that drudges through the capitalist lifestyle. Submitting to a slave wage grind of an unfufilled life without living. Freddi Fish2: The Case of the Haunted Schoolhouse is the booming echo of revitalizing humanitarinisum.\n\n-Buy they game and change your life, before you have lost the will to live.

reviewText: A story that begins as a basic search for your criminal ghost evolves into something much more complex and morally nuanced. Like in Freddi Fish 1; we’re drawn into a struggle between several groups competing to solve the mystery, and deciding which of their imperfect post-spook philosophies to align with made me pause to consider how I wanted events to play out. Even the highly questionable Institute has a tempting reason to side with them, and turning away from them in my playthrough wasn’t as clear-cut a choice as I’d expected. I was impressed by the sympathy shown toward the schoolmates, too - even the most irredeemable murderer is explored and given a trace of humanity.

reviewText: A game about making a rube goldberg-esque machine, what more could you ever want?\nWell, yeah, okay.\nArt style in this one looks a lot better for starters. The fetch quests build up to something and the puzzles are a bit trickier, or at least there's not as much handholding, though it's still pretty simple. The randomization is much better here, a variety of items to collect that ensures a pretty different game (56 different possibilities, according to the math, vs. a mere 12 in the last game). Other than that, not much else to say except good nostalgia fuel here :V
